title: Mergers and Acquisitions (M&A)

sections.title: The Strategic Logic of M&A
sections.content:
M&A refers to the consolidation of companies or assets through various types of financial transactions.

- **Merger**: The voluntary fusion of two companies on roughly equal terms into one new legal entity.
- **Acquisition**: When one company purchases most or all of another company's shares to gain control of it.
- **Takeover**: Similar to an acquisition, but often refers to a larger company purchasing a smaller one (can be friendly or hostile).
- **Synergy**: The concept that the combined value and performance of two companies will be greater than the sum of the separate individual parts.

sections.title: The M&A Lifecycle
sections.content:
A typical M&A deal involves several critical stages:

- **Due Diligence**: An investigation or audit of a potential investment or product to confirm all facts.
- **Valuation**: Determining the current worth of an asset or a company.
- **Target Company**: The company that another company is trying to buy or merge with.
- **Integration**: The process of combining the operations, cultures, and systems of two companies after a merger.

sections.title: Language Focus: Advanced Passive Structures & Nominalization
sections.content:
Professional M&A reports use formal, objective language.

- **Advanced Passive**: 
  - 'The deal **is expected** to be finalized by Q4.'
  - 'It **is believed** that the synergy will save millions.'
- **Nominalization (Turning verbs into nouns)**:
  - Instead of 'We integrated the teams,' use '**The integration** of the teams was successful.'
  - Instead of 'They valued the firm at $1B,' use '**The valuation** of the firm reached $1B.'

objectives: Distinguish between mergers, acquisitions, and takeovers
Understand the importance of synergy and due diligence
Apply formal nominalization and passive reporting in business writing
